Key Adjustments:

  1. Reduced Depth and Shadows: Compact look without excessive 3D effects.

  2. Compact Typography: Smaller text and more concise spacing.

  3. Reduced Padding and Margins: Inside cards and around the Swiper.

This version keeps the design clean, fluid, and space-efficient while maintaining a modern look.

You said:
not working make the events 300 by 500 pixel
ChatGPT said:

To make each event slide exactly 300px by 500px, we'll need to:

  • Set Fixed Dimensions: For the container and image.

  • Maintain Responsive Design: By adjusting the object fit and text wrapping.

Update for EventSlide.js:

jsx
import React from 'react';

const EventSlide = ({ imgSrc, title, details, link }) => {
  // Function to get the first 10 words from the details array
  const getFirstTenWords = () => {
    const allWords = details.join(" ").split(" ");
    return allWords.slice(0, 10).join(" ") + (allWords.length > 10 ? "..." : "");
  };

  return (
    <div
      className="event-slide"
      style={{
        width: "300px",
        height: "500px",
        backgroundColor: "white",
        borderRadius: "15px",
        overflow: "hidden",
        boxShadow: "0 4px 8px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.1)",
        transition: "transform 0.2s ease-in-out",
        display: "flex",
        flexDirection: "column",
      }}
    >
      <img
        src={imgSrc}
        alt={title}
        style={{ 
          width: "100%", 
          height: "50%", 
          objectFit: "cover" 
        }} 
      />
      <div className="down-content p-3" style={{ flexGrow: 1 }}>
        <h4 className="h5 mb-2" style={{ fontSize: "1.1rem" }}>{title}</h4>
        <p className="text-muted" style={{ fontSize: "0.9rem", marginBottom: "1rem" }}>
          {getFirstTenWords()}
        </p>
        <a
          href={link}
          className="btn btn-orange text-white w-100"
          style={{
            backgroundColor: "#ff5722",
            borderColor: "#ff5722",
            padding: "8px",
            fontSize: "0.9rem",
            borderRadius: "5px",
            textAlign: "center",
            display: "block",
            marginTop: "auto"
          }}
        >
          View More <i className="fa fa-angle-double-right"></i>
        </a>
      </div>
    </div>
  );
};

export default EventSlide;

Adjustments in SwiperSection.js:

jsx
<Swiper
  effect={"coverflow"}
  grabCursor={true}
  centeredSlides={true}
  slidesPerView={"auto"} // Use 'auto' to make it responsive with fixed width slides
  spaceBetween={30}
  coverflowEffect={{
    rotate: 10,
    stretch: 0,
    depth: 100,
    modifier: 1,
    slideShadows: false,
  }}
  autoplay={{
    delay: 2500,
    disableOnInteraction: false,
  }}
  pagination={{ clickable: true }}
  modules={[EffectCoverflow, Pagination, Autoplay]}
>
  <SwiperSlide style={{ width: "300px" }}>
    <EventSlide
      imgSrc="img/Events/e1.PNG"
      title="Android App Dev Training"
      details={[
        "Program details: Room: Gallery - 5002 (Level - 4)",
        "• 1st Day (May 28, 2015 - Thursday)",
        "• 2nd Day (May 29, 2015 - Friday)",
        "• 3rd Day (May 30, 2015 - Saturday)"
      ]}
      link="/eventPage"
    />
  </SwiperSlide>
  <SwiperSlide style={{ width: "300px" }}>
    <EventSlide
      imgSrc="img/Events/e2.PNG"
      title="Web Development Workshop"
      details={[
        "Learn modern web technologies.",
        "• Date: June 10, 2015",
        "• Time: 10:00 AM - 3:00 PM"
      ]}
      link="/eventPage2"
    />
  </SwiperSlide>
  <SwiperSlide style={{ width: "300px" }}>
    <EventSlide
      imgSrc="img/Events/e3.PNG"
      title="Tech Talk: AI in 2025"
      details={[
        "Insights from industry leaders.",
        "• Date: July 20, 2015",
        "• Venue: Main Auditorium"
      ]}
      link="/eventPage3"
    />
  </SwiperSlide>
</Swiper>

Key Changes:

  1. Fixed Width and Height: Each event box is exactly 300px by 500px.

  2. Image Adjustments: Image height is set to 50% to maintain the aspect ratio.

  3. Responsive Display: Using slidesPerView: "auto" makes the Swiper responsive.

This should make the slides consistent in size and responsive for different screen widths!

You said:
make it in the swipper
ChatGPT said:

To ensure that each event box in the Swiper is 300px by 500px and properly displayed, you'll need to set the width and height for the Swiper slides directly. Here's how you can fix it inside the Swiper setup:

Updated SwiperSection.js with fixed size for slides:

jsx
import React from "react";
// Import Swiper React components
import { Swiper, SwiperSlide } from "swiper/react";
import EventSlide from './EventSlide'; // Assuming EventSlide component is properly created

// Import Swiper styles
import "swiper/css";
import "swiper/css/effect-coverflow";
import "swiper/css/pagination";

import "./styles.css";

// import required modules
import { EffectCoverflow, Pagination, Autoplay } from "swiper";

const SwiperSection = () => {
  return (
    <>
      <section
        className="section events bg-dark-navy"
        data-section="section4"
        style={{
          position: "relative",
          backgroundColor: "#081420",
          minHeight: "60vh",
        }}
      >
        <div className="custom-shape-divider-top-1686612771">
          <svg
            data-name="Layer 1"
            xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"
            viewBox="0 0 1200 120"
            preserveAspectRatio="none"
          >
            <path
              d="M1200 120L0 16.48 0 0 1200 0 1200 120z"
              className="shape-fill"
            ></path>
          </svg>
        </div>

        <div className="container-fluid pt-5">
          <h2 className="display-6 fw-bold text-white text-center pt-2">
            Activities
          </h2>
          <div className="border-bot1 d-flex justify-content-center">
            <div className="border-line"></div>
          </div>
          <div className="row pt-0">
            <div className="col-md-12">
              <div className="section-heading">
                <a href="/pastevent.html" className="btn btn-outline-orange">
                  Jukti's Journey
                </a>
              </div>
            </div>
            <Swiper
              effect={"coverflow"}
              grabCursor={true}
              centeredSlides={true}
              slidesPerView={"auto"} // Allow auto sizing based on slide content
              spaceBetween={30} // Optional, for some spacing between slides
              coverflowEffect={{
                rotate: 10,
                stretch: 0,
                depth: 100,
                modifier: 1,
                slideShadows: false,
              }}
              autoplay={{
                delay: 2500,
                disableOnInteraction: false,
              }}
              pagination={true}
              modules={[EffectCoverflow, Pagination, Autoplay]}
            >
              {/* Add multiple SwiperSlide components with fixed size */}
              <SwiperSlide style={{ width: "300px", height: "500px" }}>
                <EventSlide
                  imgSrc="img/Events/e1.PNG"
                  title="Android App Dev Training"
                  details={[
                    "Program details: Room: Gallery - 5002 (Level - 4)",
                    "• 1st Day (May 28, 2015 - Thursday)",
                    "• 2nd Day (May 29, 2015 - Friday)",
                    "• 3rd Day (May 30, 2015 - Saturday)"
                  ]}
                  link="/eventPage"
                />
              </SwiperSlide>
              <SwiperSlide style={{ width: "300px", height: "500px" }}>
                <EventSlide
                  imgSrc="img/Events/e2.PNG"
                  title="Web Development Workshop"
                  details={[
                    "Learn modern web technologies.",
                    "• Date: June 10, 2015",
                    "• Time: 10:00 AM - 3:00 PM"
                  ]}
                  link="/eventPage2"
                />
              </SwiperSlide>
              <SwiperSlide style={{ width: "300px", height: "500px" }}>
                <EventSlide
                  imgSrc="img/Events/e3.PNG"
                  title="Tech Talk: AI in 2025"
                  details={[
                    "Insights from industry leaders.",
                    "• Date: July 20, 2015",
                    "• Venue: Main Auditorium"
                  ]}
                  link="/eventPage3"
                />
              </SwiperSlide>
            </Swiper>
          </div>
        </div>
      </section>
    </>
  );
};

export default SwiperSection;

Key Changes:

  1. Fixed Width & Height:

    • The SwiperSlide has style={{ width: "300px", height: "500px" }} to make each slide a fixed size.

    • This ensures each event will be constrained to 300px x 500px dimensions.

  2. Swiper Setup:

    • slidesPerView: "auto" allows the slides to take the fixed size and be responsive while keeping the full container width as per your requirement.

    • spaceBetween: 30 adds spacing between each slide (optional, for a more spacious layout).

  3. EventSlide Component:

    • The image and content inside the EventSlide are adapted to fit properly within the 300px by 500px box, with image sizing set to cover the top half and text adjusted accordingly.

Summary:

This approach ensures that each event box in the Swiper is 300px by 500px, and the content within adjusts to fit while keeping it responsive.

You said:
how to change a git project repo and upload it to mine
ChatGPT said:

To change a Git project repository and upload it to your own repository, follow these steps:

1. Fork the Repository (if it's on GitHub and you don't own it):

  • Go to the original repository on GitHub.

  • Click the Fork button at the top-right corner of the repository page.

  • This will create a copy of the repository in your GitHub account.

2. Clone the Repository to Your Local Machine:

If you just want to clone the original repository (not a fork), follow this:

  • Open your terminal or Git Bash.

  • Clone the repository using:

    bash
    git clone https://github.com/original-owner/repository-name.git

    Or, if you forked the repository:

    bash
    git clone https://github.com/your-username/repository-name.git

  • Replace repository-name with the actual name of the repository.

3. Change the Remote URL (if Necessary):

If you cloned a repository and want to upload it to your repository (not a fork), you'll need to change the remote URL to point to your repository.

  • Navigate to the local repository:

    bash
    cd repository-name

  • Change the remote URL to your repository:

    bash
    git remote set-url origin https://github.com/your-username/new-repository-name.git

    Replace your-username with your GitHub username and new-repository-name with the name of the new repository you want to upload it to.

4. Make Changes (if needed):

If you want to make any changes, edit the files in the repository, then add and commit your changes:

  • Add changed files:

    bash
    git add .

  • Commit your changes:

    bash
    git commit -m "Your commit message"

5. Push the Changes to Your Repository:

  • Push the changes to your remote repository:

    bash
    git push origin main

    Replace main with the branch name you're working with if it's different (e.g., master).

6. Create a New Repository on GitHub (if you haven't already):

If you haven't created a new repository on GitHub yet:

  • Go to GitHub and click on the + sign at the top-right corner.

  • Select New repository.

  • Follow the prompts to create a new repository.

  • Once created, follow the instructions provided on the repository page (e.g., git remote add).

That's it! Your local repository should now be connected to your own GitHub repository, and any changes you made should be uploaded to it.

You said:
HttpError: home/runner/work/_actions/actions/configure-pages/v5/node_modules/@octokit/request/dist-node/index.js#L124 Get Pages site failed. Please verify that the repository has Pages enabled and configured to build using GitHub Actions, or consider exploring the enablement parameter for this action. Error: Not Found - https://docs.github.com/rest/pages/pages#get-a-apiname-pages-site build
ChatGPT said:

The error you're seeing (HttpError: Not Found) usually occurs when there are issues with GitHub Pages setup or when the configuration for deploying the site is not correct. Here's how to troubleshoot and resolve the issue:

1. Ensure GitHub Pages is Enabled in Your Repository:

  • Go to your GitHub repository.

  • Click on the Settings tab.

  • Scroll down to the Pages section (under the Code and automation section).

  • Ensure that GitHub Pages is enabled, and choose the branch (e.g., main or gh-pages) and folder (e.g., /root or /docs) from which Pages should be built.

2. Check Your GitHub Actions Configuration:

Ensure that your GitHub Actions workflow is set up correctly. For deploying to GitHub Pages, your workflow YAML file (usually located at .github/workflows/ in your repo) should contain steps to build your site and deploy it.

Here's an example of a basic GitHub Actions workflow for deploying a site to GitHub Pages:

yaml
name: Deploy to GitHub Pages

on:
  push:
    branches:
      - main  # Or your default branch

jobs:
  deploy:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - name: Checkout code
        uses: actions/checkout@v2

      - name: Set up Node.js
        uses: actions/setup-node@v2
        with:
          node-version: '14'  # Or your Node.js version

      - name: Install dependencies
        run: npm install  # Adjust if using yarn or another package manager

      - name: Build the site
        run: npm run build  # Replace with your build command if different

      - name: Deploy to GitHub Pages
        uses: JamesIves/github-pages-deploy-action@v4
        with:
          branch: gh-pages  # The branch that GitHub Pages will serve from
          folder: dist  # The folder where the build is generated
          token: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}

3. Verify the GITHUB_TOKEN:

Make sure the GITHUB_TOKEN is available in the repository secrets:

  • Go to your GitHub repository.

  • Navigate to Settings > Secrets.

  • Ensure GITHUB_TOKEN is set up (it should be automatically set in most cases).

4. Check the enablement Parameter:

The error message mentions the enablement parameter. It’s possible that the enablement parameter is required for the action you're using. You might need to check the action’s documentation to see if this parameter is needed and how to configure it.

For example, in some cases, you might need to include a configuration like this:

yaml
enablement: true

Refer to the action’s documentation (e.g., @octokit/request or github-pages-deploy-action) to ensure you're using the correct parameters.

5. Check for Any Other Errors:

  • Inspect the Actions tab in your repository for any other logs or errors related to the build.

  • Review any steps in the workflow that might not be correctly configuring your build or deploying the site.

6. Re-deploy Your Site:

After making the necessary changes, commit the updates, and push them to your repository. This should trigger the GitHub Actions workflow and attempt to deploy the site again.

If the issue persists, feel free to provide more details about the error logs and configuration, and I'll help you further!

You said:
add the missing dependencies # Sample workflow for building and deploying a Next.js site to GitHub Pages # # To get started with Next.js see: https://nextjs.org/docs/getting-started # name: Deploy Next.js site to Pages on: # Runs on pushes targeting the default branch push: branches: ["master"] # Allows you to run this workflow manually from the Actions tab workflow_dispatch: # Sets permissions of the GITHUB_TOKEN to allow deployment to GitHub Pages permissions: contents: read pages: write id-token: write # Allow only one concurrent deployment, skipping runs queued between the run in-progress and latest queued. # However, do NOT cancel in-progress runs as we want to allow these production deployments to complete. concurrency: group: "pages" cancel-in-progress: false jobs: # Build job build: runs-on: ubuntu-latest steps: - name: Checkout uses: actions/checkout@v4 - name: Detect package manager id: detect-package-manager run: | if [ -f "${{ github.workspace }}/yarn.lock" ]; then echo "manager=yarn" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT echo "command=install" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT echo "runner=yarn" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT exit 0 elif [ -f "${{ github.workspace }}/package.json" ]; then echo "manager=npm" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT echo "command=ci" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT echo "runner=npx --no-install" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT exit 0 else echo "Unable to determine package manager" exit 1 fi - name: Setup Node uses: actions/setup-node@v4 with: node-version: "20" cache: ${{ steps.detect-package-manager.outputs.manager }} - name: Setup Pages uses: actions/configure-pages@v5 with: # Automatically inject basePath in your Next.js configuration file and disable # server side image optimization (https://nextjs.org/docs/api-reference/next/image#unoptimized). # # You may remove this line if you want to manage the configuration yourself. static_site_generator: next - name: Restore cache uses: actions/cache@v4 with: path: | .next/cache # Generate a new cache whenever packages or source files change. key: ${{ runner.os }}-nextjs-${{ hashFiles('**/package-lock.json', '**/yarn.lock') }}-${{ hashFiles('**.[jt]s', '**.[jt]sx') }} # If source files changed but packages didn't, rebuild from a prior cache. restore-keys: | ${{ runner.os }}-nextjs-${{ hashFiles('**/package-lock.json', '**/yarn.lock') }}- - name: Install dependencies run: ${{ steps.detect-package-manager.outputs.manager }} ${{ steps.detect-package-manager.outputs.command }} - name: Build with Next.js run: ${{ steps.detect-package-manager.outputs.runner }} next build - name: Upload artifact uses: actions/upload-pages-artifact@v3 with: path: ./out # Deployment job deploy: environment: name: github-pages url: ${{ steps.deployment.outputs.page_url }} runs-on: ubuntu-latest needs: build steps: - name: Deploy to GitHub Pages id: deployment uses: actions/deploy-pages@v4
ChatGPT said:

To ensure that the missing dependencies and steps are added to the workflow for building and deploying a Next.js site to GitHub Pages, I will go through the steps and include any necessary adjustments.

Here’s the updated and complete GitHub Actions workflow that covers all the dependencies and steps for deployment:

yaml
name: Deploy Next.js site to Pages

on:
  # Runs on pushes targeting the default branch
  push:
    branches: ["master"]

  # Allows you to run this workflow manually from the Actions tab
  workflow_dispatch:

# Sets permissions of the GITHUB_TOKEN to allow deployment to GitHub Pages
permissions:
  contents: read
  pages: write
  id-token: write

# Allow only one concurrent deployment, skipping runs queued between the run in-progress and latest queued.
# However, do NOT cancel in-progress runs as we want to allow these production deployments to complete.
concurrency:
  group: "pages"
  cancel-in-progress: false

jobs:
  # Build job
  build:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - name: Checkout
        uses: actions/checkout@v4

      - name: Detect package manager
        id: detect-package-manager
        run: |
          if [ -f "${{ github.workspace }}/yarn.lock" ]; then
            echo "manager=yarn" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT
            echo "command=install" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT
            echo "runner=yarn" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT
            exit 0
          elif [ -f "${{ github.workspace }}/package.json" ]; then
            echo "manager=npm" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT
            echo "command=ci" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT
            echo "runner=npx --no-install" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT
            exit 0
          else
            echo "Unable to determine package manager"
            exit 1
          fi

      - name: Setup Node
        uses: actions/setup-node@v4
        with:
          node-version: "20"
          cache: ${{ steps.detect-package-manager.outputs.manager }}

      - name: Setup Pages
        uses: actions/configure-pages@v5
        with:
          # Automatically inject basePath in your Next.js configuration file and disable
          # server-side image optimization (https://nextjs.org/docs/api-reference/next/image#unoptimized).
          #
          # You may remove this line if you want to manage the configuration yourself.
          static_site_generator: next

      - name: Restore cache
        uses: actions/cache@v4
        with:
          path: |
            .next/cache
          # Generate a new cache whenever packages or source files change.
          key: ${{ runner.os }}-nextjs-${{ hashFiles('**/package-lock.json', '**/yarn.lock') }}-${{ hashFiles('**.[jt]s', '**.[jt]sx') }}
          # If source files changed but packages didn't, rebuild from a prior cache.
          restore-keys: |
            ${{ runner.os }}-nextjs-${{ hashFiles('**/package-lock.json', '**/yarn.lock') }}-

      - name: Install dependencies
        run: ${{ steps.detect-package-manager.outputs.manager }} ${{ steps.detect-package-manager.outputs.command }}

      - name: Build with Next.js
        run: ${{ steps.detect-package-manager.outputs.runner }} next build

      - name: Export Next.js site
        run: ${{ steps.detect-package-manager.outputs.runner }} next export
        # Make sure to export the site to the correct folder
        # By default, it exports to `/out`

      - name: Upload artifact
        uses: actions/upload-pages-artifact@v3
        with:
          path: ./out

  # Deployment job
  deploy:
    environment:
      name: github-pages
      url: ${{ steps.deployment.outputs.page_url }}
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    needs: build
    steps:
      - name: Deploy to GitHub Pages
        id: deployment
        uses: actions/deploy-pages@v4

Key Updates:

  1. Detect Package Manager: The workflow detects whether you’re using npm or yarn and sets the appropriate variables for installation.

  2. Node Setup: The workflow uses actions/setup-node to ensure that the correct version of Node.js (v20) is used for the build process.

  3. Next.js Export: Added a step to run next export to generate static HTML files, which GitHub Pages will use to serve the site. This step creates the out directory.

  4. Upload Artifact: The upload-pages-artifact step uploads the content from the out directory to be deployed on GitHub Pages.

  5. Deployment: Finally, the deploy-pages action deploys the content from the out directory to GitHub Pages.

Missing Dependencies:

The workflow uses the following dependencies:

  • next: Make sure it's listed in your package.json.

  • yarn or npm: Depending on your choice of package manager, you may need to install either of them. Ensure that the appropriate lock file (yarn.lock or package-lock.json) is present in your project.

Make sure you have:

  1. next installed:

    bash
    npm install next react react-dom

  2. Ensure next.config.js is properly configured if you need custom settings for the deployment.

  3. Exporting the site: The command next export is used to export your Next.js site as static files to be served by GitHub Pages. Make sure the out folder is generated after this command.

After this configuration, your GitHub Pages deployment should work properly.

You said:
./app/components/benefits.tsx:2:20 Type error: Could not find a declaration file for module 'react-slick'. '/home/runner/work/JUKTI--Web-NextJs/JUKTI--Web-NextJs/node_modules/react-slick/lib/index.js' implicitly has an 'any' type. Try npm i --save-dev @types/react-slick if it exists or add a new declaration (.d.ts) file containing declare module 'react-slick'; 1 | import React from "react"; > 2 | import Slider from "react-slick"; | ^ 3 | import "slick-carousel/slick/slick.css"; 4 | import "slick-carousel/slick/slick-theme.css"; 5 | import { useMediaQuery } from "react-responsive"; Error: Process completed with exit code 1. ##[debug]Finishing: Build with Next.js
ChatGPT said:

The error you're encountering is caused by TypeScript not finding type declarations for the react-slick module. This happens because react-slick doesn't provide its own type definitions, and TypeScript requires type information for third-party modules.

To fix this issue, you can follow the steps below:

1. Install @types/react-slick

You can install the type definitions for react-slick using the following command:

bash
npm install --save-dev @types/react-slick

This will install the necessary type declarations for react-slick, allowing TypeScript to recognize the module and eliminate the error.

2. Declare Module Manually (If Type Definitions Are Not Available)

If the type definitions for react-slick are not available, or you encounter other issues, you can declare the module yourself.

Create a declarations.d.ts file in the root of your project (or in the src folder), and add the following content:

ts
declare module 'react-slick' {
  const Slider: any;
  export default Slider;
}

This will tell TypeScript to treat react-slick as an any type and bypass the type checking for that module.

3. Re-run the Build

After installing the necessary types or adding the manual declaration, re-run your build to see if the issue is resolved.

bash
npm run build

Recap:

  • First, try installing the type definitions with npm install --save-dev @types/react-slick.

  • If that doesn’t work, create a declarations.d.ts file to declare react-slick with the any type.

  • Finally, re-run the build to ensure everything works correctly.

Let me know if this solves your issue!

You said:
add to workflow
ChatGPT said:

To add the installation of @types/react-slick to your GitHub Actions workflow, you'll need to modify the Install dependencies step so that it installs this package as part of your build process.

Here is how you can modify your workflow file:

yaml
# Sample workflow for building and deploying a Next.js site to GitHub Pages
#
# To get started with Next.js see: https://nextjs.org/docs/getting-started
#
name: Deploy Next.js site to Pages

on:
  # Runs on pushes targeting the default branch
  push:
    branches: ["master"]

  # Allows you to run this workflow manually from the Actions tab
  workflow_dispatch:

# Sets permissions of the GITHUB_TOKEN to allow deployment to GitHub Pages
permissions:
  contents: read
  pages: write
  id-token: write

# Allow only one concurrent deployment, skipping runs queued between the run in-progress and latest queued.
# However, do NOT cancel in-progress runs as we want to allow these production deployments to complete.
concurrency:
  group: "pages"
  cancel-in-progress: false

jobs:
  # Build job
  build:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - name: Checkout
        uses: actions/checkout@v4
      - name: Detect package manager
        id: detect-package-manager
        run: |
          if [ -f "${{ github.workspace }}/yarn.lock" ]; then
            echo "manager=yarn" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT
            echo "command=install" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT
            echo "runner=yarn" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT
            exit 0
          elif [ -f "${{ github.workspace }}/package.json" ]; then
            echo "manager=npm" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT
            echo "command=ci" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT
            echo "runner=npx --no-install" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT
            exit 0
          else
            echo "Unable to determine package manager"
            exit 1
          fi
      - name: Setup Node
        uses: actions/setup-node@v4
        with:
          node-version: "20"
          cache: ${{ steps.detect-package-manager.outputs.manager }}
      - name: Setup Pages
        uses: actions/configure-pages@v5
        with:
          # Automatically inject basePath in your Next.js configuration file and disable
          # server side image optimization (https://nextjs.org/docs/api-reference/next/image#unoptimized).
          #
          # You may remove this line if you want to manage the configuration yourself.
          static_site_generator: next
      - name: Restore cache
        uses: actions/cache@v4
        with:
          path: |
            .next/cache
          # Generate a new cache whenever packages or source files change.
          key: ${{ runner.os }}-nextjs-${{ hashFiles('**/package-lock.json', '**/yarn.lock') }}-${{ hashFiles('**.[jt]s', '**.[jt]sx') }}
          # If source files changed but packages didn't, rebuild from a prior cache.
          restore-keys: |
            ${{ runner.os }}-nextjs-${{ hashFiles('**/package-lock.json', '**/yarn.lock') }}-
      - name: Install dependencies
        run: |
          # Install react-slick types
          npm install --save-dev @types/react-slick
          # Install other dependencies
          ${{ steps.detect-package-manager.outputs.manager }} ${{ steps.detect-package-manager.outputs.command }}
      - name: Build with Next.js
        run: ${{ steps.detect-package-manager.outputs.runner }} next build
      - name: Upload artifact
        uses: actions/upload-pages-artifact@v3
        with:
          path: ./out

  # Deployment job
  deploy:
    environment:
      name: github-pages
      url: ${{ steps.deployment.outputs.page_url }}
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    needs: build
    steps:
      - name: Deploy to GitHub Pages
        id: deployment
        uses: actions/deploy-pages@v4

Changes made:

  1. Install react-slick types: I added the line npm install --save-dev @types/react-slick inside the Install dependencies step. This ensures that the type definitions for react-slick are installed before building the application.

Now, your workflow will:

  1. Checkout the code.

  2. Detect the package manager (npm or yarn).

  3. Set up Node.js.

  4. Restore cache for faster builds.

  5. Install dependencies (including @types/react-slick).

  6. Build the Next.js app.

  7. Upload the artifact.

  8. Deploy to GitHub Pages.

Let me know if you need any further assistance!

You said:
give the full workflow file
ChatGPT said:

Here's the complete workflow file with the necessary changes:

yaml
# Sample workflow for building and deploying a Next.js site to GitHub Pages
#
# To get started with Next.js see: https://nextjs.org/docs/getting-started
#
name: Deploy Next.js site to Pages

on:
  # Runs on pushes targeting the default branch
  push:
    branches: ["master"]

  # Allows you to run this workflow manually from the Actions tab
  workflow_dispatch:

# Sets permissions of the GITHUB_TOKEN to allow deployment to GitHub Pages
permissions:
  contents: read
  pages: write
  id-token: write

# Allow only one concurrent deployment, skipping runs queued between the run in-progress and latest queued.
# However, do NOT cancel in-progress runs as we want to allow these production deployments to complete.
concurrency:
  group: "pages"
  cancel-in-progress: false

jobs:
  # Build job
  build:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - name: Checkout
        uses: actions/checkout@v4
      - name: Detect package manager
        id: detect-package-manager
        run: |
          if [ -f "${{ github.workspace }}/yarn.lock" ]; then
            echo "manager=yarn" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT
            echo "command=install" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT
            echo "runner=yarn" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT
            exit 0
          elif [ -f "${{ github.workspace }}/package.json" ]; then
            echo "manager=npm" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT
            echo "command=ci" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT
            echo "runner=npx --no-install" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT
            exit 0
          else
            echo "Unable to determine package manager"
            exit 1
          fi
      - name: Setup Node
        uses: actions/setup-node@v4
        with:
          node-version: "20"
          cache: ${{ steps.detect-package-manager.outputs.manager }}
      - name: Setup Pages
        uses: actions/configure-pages@v5
        with:
          # Automatically inject basePath in your Next.js configuration file and disable
          # server side image optimization (https://nextjs.org/docs/api-reference/next/image#unoptimized).
          #
          # You may remove this line if you want to manage the configuration yourself.
          static_site_generator: next
      - name: Restore cache
        uses: actions/cache@v4
        with:
          path: |
            .next/cache
          # Generate a new cache whenever packages or source files change.
          key: ${{ runner.os }}-nextjs-${{ hashFiles('**/package-lock.json', '**/yarn.lock') }}-${{ hashFiles('**.[jt]s', '**.[jt]sx') }}
          # If source files changed but packages didn't, rebuild from a prior cache.
          restore-keys: |
            ${{ runner.os }}-nextjs-${{ hashFiles('**/package-lock.json', '**/yarn.lock') }}-
      - name: Install dependencies
        run: |
          # Install react-slick types
          npm install --save-dev @types/react-slick
          # Install other dependencies
          ${{ steps.detect-package-manager.outputs.manager }} ${{ steps.detect-package-manager.outputs.command }}
      - name: Build with Next.js
        run: ${{ steps.detect-package-manager.outputs.runner }} next build
      - name: Upload artifact
        uses: actions/upload-pages-artifact@v3
        with:
          path: ./out

  # Deployment job
  deploy:
    environment:
      name: github-pages
      url: ${{ steps.deployment.outputs.page_url }}
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    needs: build
    steps:
      - name: Deploy to GitHub Pages
        id: deployment
        uses: actions/deploy-pages@v4

Key Changes:

  • Install react-slick types: The line npm install --save-dev @types/react-slick was added to the Install dependencies step to resolve the TypeScript error related to react-slick.

Workflow Breakdown:

  1. on.push: The workflow triggers on pushes to the master branch.

  2. Permissions: Grants necessary permissions to read content and deploy pages.

  3. Concurrency: Ensures only one deployment runs at a time.

  4. Build job:

    • Checkout: Pulls the repository code.

    • Detect package manager: Identifies whether npm or yarn is used.

    • Setup Node: Installs the Node.js environment.

    • Setup Pages: Configures GitHub Pages for static site deployment.

    • Restore cache: Caches dependencies for faster builds.

    • Install dependencies: Installs @types/react-slick and other dependencies.

    • Build: Builds the Next.js site.

    • Upload artifact: Prepares the build output for deployment.

  5. Deploy job:

    • Deploy to GitHub Pages: Deploys the built site to GitHub Pages.

Now your GitHub Actions workflow includes the necessary installation of type definitions for react-slick and should run without errors related to missing types. Let me know if you need further adjustments!

You said:
add react-icon and react-responsive
ChatGPT said:

Here's the updated workflow file with the installation of react-icons and react-responsive dependencies:

yaml
# Sample workflow for building and deploying a Next.js site to GitHub Pages
#
# To get started with Next.js see: https://nextjs.org/docs/getting-started
#
name: Deploy Next.js site to Pages

on:
  # Runs on pushes targeting the default branch
  push:
    branches: ["master"]

  # Allows you to run this workflow manually from the Actions tab
  workflow_dispatch:

# Sets permissions of the GITHUB_TOKEN to allow deployment to GitHub Pages
permissions:
  contents: read
  pages: write
  id-token: write

# Allow only one concurrent deployment, skipping runs queued between the run in-progress and latest queued.
# However, do NOT cancel in-progress runs as we want to allow these production deployments to complete.
concurrency:
  group: "pages"
  cancel-in-progress: false

jobs:
  # Build job
  build:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - name: Checkout
        uses: actions/checkout@v4
      - name: Detect package manager
        id: detect-package-manager
        run: |
          if [ -f "${{ github.workspace }}/yarn.lock" ]; then
            echo "manager=yarn" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT
            echo "command=install" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT
            echo "runner=yarn" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT
            exit 0
          elif [ -f "${{ github.workspace }}/package.json" ]; then
            echo "manager=npm" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT
            echo "command=ci" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT
            echo "runner=npx --no-install" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT
            exit 0
          else
            echo "Unable to determine package manager"
            exit 1
          fi
      - name: Setup Node
        uses: actions/setup-node@v4
        with:
          node-version: "20"
          cache: ${{ steps.detect-package-manager.outputs.manager }}
      - name: Setup Pages
        uses: actions/configure-pages@v5
        with:
          # Automatically inject basePath in your Next.js configuration file and disable
          # server side image optimization (https://nextjs.org/docs/api-reference/next/image#unoptimized).
          #
          # You may remove this line if you want to manage the configuration yourself.
          static_site_generator: next
      - name: Restore cache
        uses: actions/cache@v4
        with:
          path: |
            .next/cache
          # Generate a new cache whenever packages or source files change.
          key: ${{ runner.os }}-nextjs-${{ hashFiles('**/package-lock.json', '**/yarn.lock') }}-${{ hashFiles('**.[jt]s', '**.[jt]sx') }}
          # If source files changed but packages didn't, rebuild from a prior cache.
          restore-keys: |
            ${{ runner.os }}-nextjs-${{ hashFiles('**/package-lock.json', '**/yarn.lock') }}-
      - name: Install dependencies
        run: |
          # Install required dependencies
          npm install --save-dev @types/react-slick
          npm install --save react-icons react-responsive
          # Install other dependencies
          ${{ steps.detect-package-manager.outputs.manager }} ${{ steps.detect-package-manager.outputs.command }}
      - name: Build with Next.js
        run: ${{ steps.detect-package-manager.outputs.runner }} next build
      - name: Upload artifact
        uses: actions/upload-pages-artifact@v3
        with:
          path: ./out

  # Deployment job
  deploy:
    environment:
      name: github-pages
      url: ${{ steps.deployment.outputs.page_url }}
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    needs: build
    steps:
      - name: Deploy to GitHub Pages
        id: deployment
        uses: actions/deploy-pages@v4

Key Changes:

  • Install react-icons and react-responsive: The line npm install --save react-icons react-responsive was added to the Install dependencies step to install both react-icons and react-responsive.

Workflow Breakdown:

  1. on.push: The workflow triggers on pushes to the master branch.

  2. Permissions: Grants necessary permissions to read content and deploy pages.

  3. Concurrency: Ensures only one deployment runs at a time.

  4. Build job:

    • Checkout: Pulls the repository code.

    • Detect package manager: Identifies whether npm or yarn is used.

    • Setup Node: Installs the Node.js environment.

    • Setup Pages: Configures GitHub Pages for static site deployment.

    • Restore cache: Caches dependencies for faster builds.

    • Install dependencies: Installs react-slick types, react-icons, react-responsive, and other dependencies.

    • Build: Builds the Next.js site.

    • Upload artifact: Prepares the build output for deployment.

  5. Deploy job:

    • Deploy to GitHub Pages: Deploys the built site to GitHub Pages.

Let me know if you need further adjustments!

You said:
make a proper dependency file
ChatGPT said:

Here’s the proper dependency file (package.json) to go along with the GitHub Actions workflow, including react-icons, react-responsive, and other necessary dependencies for your Next.js project:

json
{
  "name": "your-project-name",
  "version": "1.0.0",
  "description": "A Next.js project deployed to GitHub Pages",
  "main": "index.js",
  "scripts": {
    "dev": "next dev",
    "build": "next build",
    "start": "next start",
    "lint": "next lint",
    "postinstall": "next export"
  },
  "dependencies": {
    "react": "^18.2.0",
    "react-dom": "^18.2.0",
    "next": "^13.3.0",
    "react-icons": "^4.4.0",
    "react-responsive": "^9.0.0",
    "slick-carousel": "^1.8.1",
    "react-slick": "^0.28.1"
  },
  "devDependencies": {
    "@types/react-slick": "^0.28.1",
    "typescript": "^4.5.4",
    "eslint": "^7.32.0",
    "eslint-config-next": "^12.0.7"
  },
  "engines": {
    "node": ">=12.0.0"
  },
  "license": "MIT"
}

Key Sections:

  • dependencies: This includes the core dependencies such as react, react-dom, next, react-icons, react-responsive, and react-slick.

  • devDependencies: This includes the development dependencies like @types/react-slick (for TypeScript type support), TypeScript, ESLint, and Next.js ESLint config.

  • scripts: These are the default Next.js scripts (dev, build, start, lint, etc.) to run and build your app.

  • engines: Specifies the minimum required Node.js version.

After Adding the package.json:

  1. Install dependencies: Run the following command to install all the dependencies.

    bash
    npm install

  2. Run the project locally:

    • Run the development server:

      bash
      npm run dev

    • Build the project:

      bash
      npm run build

Once you’ve set up the package.json with these dependencies, this will match your GitHub Actions workflow for proper build and deployment.

Let me know if you need any other modifications!

You said:
Failed to compile. ./app/components/event_slide.tsx:3:23 Type error: Binding element 'imgSrc' implicitly has an 'any' type. 1 | import React from 'react'; 2 | > 3 | const EventSlide = ({ imgSrc, title, details, link }) => { | ^ 4 | // Function to get the first 10 words from the details array 5 | const getFirstTenWords = () => { 6 | const allWords = details.join(" ").split(" "); Error: Process completed with exit code 1.
ChatGPT said:

The error you're seeing is happening because TypeScript is not able to infer the types for the props in your EventSlide component.

To fix this, you need to define types for the props that the EventSlide component expects. You can do this by declaring an interface for the props.

Here’s how you can update your EventSlide component to resolve the error:

Updated event_slide.tsx:

tsx
import React from 'react';

// Define the types for the props
interface EventSlideProps {
  imgSrc: string;
  title: string;
  details: string[];
  link: string;
}

const EventSlide: React.FC<EventSlideProps> = ({ imgSrc, title, details, link }) => {
  // Function to get the first 10 words from the details array
  const getFirstTenWords = () => {
    const allWords = details.join(" ").split(" ");
    return allWords.slice(0, 10).join(" ") + (allWords.length > 10 ? "..." : "");
  };

  return (
    <div
      className="p-3 w-100"
      style={{
        backgroundColor: "white",
        borderRadius: "15px",  // Rounded corners
        overflow: "hidden",   // Prevent content from overflowing
        boxShadow: "0 4px 8px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.1)", // Soft shadow for professional look
        transition: "transform 0.2s ease-in-out", // Smooth hover effect
      }}
    >
      <img
        src={imgSrc}
        alt={title}
        className="img-fluid"
        style={{ 
          width: "100%", 
          height: "auto", 
          objectFit: "cover", 
          borderTopLeftRadius: "15px", 
          borderTopRightRadius: "15px" 
        }} 
      />
      <div className="down-content px-3 pt-3 pb-2">
        <h4 className="h5 mb-2" style={{ fontSize: "clamp(1rem, 2vw, 1.5rem)" }}>{title}</h4>
        <p className="text-muted" style={{ fontSize: "clamp(0.8rem, 1.5vw, 1rem)", marginBottom: "0.5rem" }}>
          {getFirstTenWords()}
        </p>
        <div className="text-button-pay">
          <a
            href={link}
            className="btn btn-orange text-white mt-2 w-100"
            style={{
              backgroundColor: "#ff5722",
              borderColor: "#ff5722",
              padding: "10px",
              fontSize: "clamp(0.9rem, 1.5vw, 1.1rem)", // Fluid typography for button text
              borderRadius: "5px",
              textAlign: "center",
              display: "block",
            }}
          >
            View More <i className="fa fa-angle-double-right"></i>
          </a>
        </div>
      </div>
    </div>
  );
};

export default EventSlide;

Explanation:

  1. Interface (EventSlideProps): This defines the types for the props. The imgSrc is a string, title is a string, details is an array of strings (string[]), and link is a string.

  2. React.FC: The React.FC<EventSlideProps> indicates that the component is a functional component that accepts EventSlideProps as its props.

  3. TypeScript in React: By using TypeScript’s interface, you can enforce the types for the props, preventing the error you encountered.

Now TypeScript will know the types of the props, and this should resolve the error you're seeing in the GitHub Actions build.

You said:
make the google form responsive import React from "react"; // import "./reg.css"; const GFormReg = () => { return ( <> <section className="bg-dark-navy"> <div className="container d-flex flex-column justify-content-center align-items-center py-5"> <h2 className="display-1 text-light">Become a member</h2> <p className="text-light text-center lead"> Ready to become a member? Register now to join our community and gain access to exclusive benefits and exciting opportunities! </p> </div> </section> <div className="container my-5"> <div className="row justify-content-center"> <div className="col-lg-8"> <div className="registration-form"> <h3 className="fw-bold">Recruitment Form</h3> <p className="lead">Fill out the form below to register:</p> <iframe src="https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSc4cRZmrevMm5CrFnhHvmYWeJysSAynrQcaJXCkYVaAsBXAwQ/viewform?embedded=true" width="400" height="800" frameborder="0" marginheight="0" marginwidth="0">Loading…</iframe> </div> </div> </div> </div> </> ); }; export default GFormReg;
ChatGPT said:

To make the embedded Google Form responsive, you should use CSS to ensure it scales appropriately on different screen sizes. The best approach is to wrap the iframe in a responsive container and adjust its width and height using CSS.

Here's how to update your component to make the Google Form responsive:

Updated Component (GFormReg.tsx):

tsx
import React from "react";

const GFormReg = () => {
  return (
    <>
      <section className="bg-dark-navy">
        <div className="container d-flex flex-column justify-content-center align-items-center py-5">
          <h2 className="display-1 text-light text-center">Become a member</h2>
          <p className="text-light text-center lead">
            Ready to become a member? Register now to join our community and
            gain access to exclusive benefits and exciting opportunities!
          </p>
        </div>
      </section>
      <div className="container my-5">
        <div className="row justify-content-center">
          <div className="col-lg-8">
            <div className="registration-form">
              <h3 className="fw-bold text-center">Recruitment Form</h3>
              <p className="lead text-center">
                Fill out the form below to register:
              </p>
              <div className="iframe-container">
                <iframe
                  src="https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSc4cRZmrevMm5CrFnhHvmYWeJysSAynrQcaJXCkYVaAsBXAwQ/viewform?embedded=true"
                  frameBorder="0"
                  marginHeight="0"
                  marginWidth="0"
                  title="Recruitment Form"
                  allowFullScreen
                >
                  Loading…
                </iframe>
              </div>
            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </div>
    </>
  );
};

export default GFormReg;

Add the CSS:

Add the following CSS to make the iframe responsive:

css
.iframe-container {
  position: relative;
  width: 100%;
  padding-top: 56.25%; /* Aspect ratio 16:9 */
  overflow: hidden;
  border-radius: 8px; /* Optional: Rounded corners */
  box-shadow: 0 4px 8px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.2); /* Optional: Box shadow */
}

.iframe-container iframe {
  position: absolute;
  top: 0;
  left: 0;
  width: 100%;
  height: 100%;
  border: 0;
}

Explanation:

  1. Responsive Aspect Ratio: The .iframe-container class sets the width to 100% and the padding-top to 56.25%, maintaining a 16:9 aspect ratio. This keeps the iframe responsive.

  2. Positioning: The iframe is absolutely positioned within the container to ensure it scales properly.

  3. Rounded Corners and Shadow: Added some optional styling for a polished look.

This approach will make the Google Form responsive, adapting to different screen sizes on mobile, tablet, and desktop.

You said:
hide the iframe scroll bar or make it look good
ChatGPT said:

To hide the scroll bar of the embedded Google Form or make it look cleaner, you can use the following approaches:

1. Hide Scroll Bar (Cross-browser Compatible):

Use CSS to hide the scrollbar while still allowing scrolling.

2. Customize Scroll Bar (For WebKit Browsers):

Make the scrollbar minimalistic and less obtrusive.

Updated CSS:

css
.iframe-container {
  position: relative;
  width: 100%;
  padding-top: 56.25%; /* Aspect ratio 16:9 */
  overflow: hidden;
  border-radius: 8px;
  box-shadow: 0 4px 8px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.2);
}

.iframe-container iframe {
  position: absolute;
  top: 0;
  left: 0;
  width: 100%;
  height: 100%;
  border: 0;
  overflow: hidden;
  scrollbar-width: none; /* For Firefox */
}

/* Hide scrollbar for WebKit browsers (Chrome, Safari) */
.iframe-container iframe::-webkit-scrollbar {
  display: none;
}

Alternative: Minimalistic Scroll Bar (Optional)

If you prefer to style the scrollbar rather than hide it, use the following instead:

css
/* Minimalistic scrollbar for WebKit browsers */
.iframe-container iframe::-webkit-scrollbar {
  width: 8px;
}

.iframe-container iframe::-webkit-scrollbar-thumb {
  background: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.3);
  border-radius: 4px;
}

.iframe-container iframe::-webkit-scrollbar-thumb:hover {
  background: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5);
}

.iframe-container iframe::-webkit-scrollbar-track {
  background: transparent;
}

Explanation:

  1. Hiding Scrollbar:

    • scrollbar-width: none; for Firefox.

    • ::-webkit-scrollbar { display: none; } for Chrome and Safari.

  2. Minimalistic Style:

    • A thin scrollbar with rounded corners and subtle hover effects.

These styles ensure a cleaner and more polished look for the embedded Google Form while maintaining functionality.

You said:
add a form with one input field that will take student id as input , and check status btn, on clicking the button it will do a get request to a api to retreive result and show status, only two status Approved, Rejected , if no result then show id not found import React from "react"; const Result = () => { return ( <> <section className="bg-dark-navy"> <div className="container d-flex flex-column justify-content-center align-items-center py-5"> <h2 className="display-1 text-light text-center">Recruitment Result</h2> <p className="text-light text-center lead"> Applied to become a member? </p> </div> </section> <div className="container my-5"> <div className="row justify-content-center"> <div className="col-lg-8"> <div className="registration-form"> <h3 className="fw-bold text-center">Application Status</h3> <p className="lead text-center"> Fill out the form below to check application status: </p> </div> </div> </div> </div> </> ); }; export default Result;
ChatGPT said:

Here's the updated React component that includes:

  • An input field for the student ID.

  • A "Check Status" button.

  • A GET request to check the status.

  • Status display: "Approved," "Rejected," or "ID not found."

Updated Code:

js
import React, { useState } from "react";
import axios from "axios";

const Result = () => {
  const [studentId, setStudentId] = useState("");
  const [status, setStatus] = useState("");
  const [loading, setLoading] = useState(false);

  const checkStatus = async () => {
    if (!studentId) {
      setStatus("Please enter a valid student ID.");
      return;
    }
    setLoading(true);
    setStatus("");

    try {
      const response = await axios.get(
        `https://example.com/api/status/${studentId}`
      );
      const result = response.data.status;
      if (result === "Approved" || result === "Rejected") {
        setStatus(result);
      } else {
        setStatus("ID not found");
      }
    } catch (error) {
      setStatus("Error retrieving status. Please try again later.");
    } finally {
      setLoading(false);
    }
  };

  return (
    <>
      <section className="bg-dark-navy">
        <div className="container d-flex flex-column justify-content-center align-items-center py-5">
          <h2 className="display-1 text-light text-center">Recruitment Result</h2>
          <p className="text-light text-center lead">
            Applied to become a member?
          </p>
        </div>
      </section>
      <div className="container my-5">
        <div className="row justify-content-center">
          <div className="col-lg-8">
            <div className="registration-form text-center">
              <h3 className="fw-bold">Application Status</h3>
              <p className="lead">
                Enter your student ID to check application status:
              </p>
              <input
                type="text"
                className="form-control mb-3"
                placeholder="Enter Student ID"
                value={studentId}
                onChange={(e) => setStudentId(e.target.value)}
              />
              <button
                className="btn btn-primary"
                onClick={checkStatus}
                disabled={loading}
              >
                {loading ? "Checking..." : "Check Status"}
              </button>
              {status && (
                <div className="mt-3 alert alert-info">{status}</div>
              )}
            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </div>
    </>
  );
};

export default Result;

Key Features:

  1. Input Field: Captures the student ID.

  2. Button: Triggers the GET request to the API.

  3. GET Request: Uses Axios to make the request.

  4. Conditional Rendering:

    • Shows "Approved," "Rejected," or "ID not found" based on API response.

    • Displays loading state while the request is being processed.

Required Dependencies:

If you haven't already, install Axios using:

bash
npm install axios

or

bash
yarn add axios

Notes:

  • Replace https://example.com/api/status/${studentId} with the actual API endpoint.

  • The component handles errors gracefully and shows an appropriate message if the request fails.

Feel free to adjust the styles or messaging to better fit your project's design!

You said:
do this for nextjs
ChatGPT said:

Here's how to implement the form in Next.js:

  • Uses the useState hook for state management.

  • Makes a GET request using Axios to check the status.

  • Displays Approved, Rejected, or ID not found.

Next.js Component:

js
"use client";

import React, { useState } from "react";
import axios from "axios";

const Result = () => {
  const [studentId, setStudentId] = useState("");
  const [status, setStatus] = useState("");
  const [loading, setLoading] = useState(false);

  const checkStatus = async () => {
    if (!studentId) {
      setStatus("Please enter a valid student ID.");
      return;
    }
    setLoading(true);
    setStatus("");

    try {
      const response = await axios.get(
        `/api/status?id=${studentId}`
      );
      const result = response.data.status;
      if (result === "Approved" || result === "Rejected") {
        setStatus(result);
      } else {
        setStatus("ID not found");
      }
    } catch (error) {
      setStatus("Error retrieving status. Please try again later.");
    } finally {
      setLoading(false);
    }
  };

  return (
    <>
      <section className="bg-dark-navy">
        <div className="container d-flex flex-column justify-content-center align-items-center py-5">
          <h2 className="display-1 text-light text-center">Recruitment Result</h2>
          <p className="text-light text-center lead">
            Applied to become a member?
          </p>
        </div>
      </section>
      <div className="container my-5">
        <div className="row justify-content-center">
          <div className="col-lg-8">
            <div className="registration-form text-center">
              <h3 className="fw-bold">Application Status</h3>
              <p className="lead">
                Enter your student ID to check application status:
              </p>
              <input
                type="text"
                className="form-control mb-3"
                placeholder="Enter Student ID"
                value={studentId}
                onChange={(e) => setStudentId(e.target.value)}
              />
              <button
                className="btn btn-primary"
                onClick={checkStatus}
                disabled={loading}
              >
                {loading ? "Checking..." : "Check Status"}
              </button>
              {status && (
                <div className="mt-3 alert alert-info">{status}</div>
              )}
            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </div>
    </>
  );
};

export default Result;

Setting up the API Route:

Create a new file:
/app/api/status/route.js

js
import { NextResponse } from 'next/server';

export async function GET(request) {
  const { searchParams } = new URL(request.url);
  const id = searchParams.get("id");

  // Mock data for demo purposes
  const data = {
    "12345": "Approved",
    "67890": "Rejected",
  };

  // Simulate checking the status
  const status = data[id] || null;

  return NextResponse.json({ status });
}

Required Dependencies:

If you haven't already, install Axios:

bash
npm install axios

or

bash
yarn add axios

Key Features:

  • Input Field: Captures the student ID.

  • Button: Triggers the GET request to the API.

  • API Route: Uses Next.js App Router to handle the request.

  • Conditional Rendering:

    • Displays "Approved," "Rejected," or "ID not found" based on API response.

    • Shows loading state while processing the request.

Notes:

  • Adjust the mock data or connect to your actual database or API.

  • This example uses the App Router of Next.js 13+.

  • If you're using the Pages Router, adjust the API route accordingly.

Feel free to adjust the styles or messaging to better fit your project's design!

You said:
make the form look good, add a container , make accent color orrange
ChatGPT said:

Here's the enhanced version of the Next.js component:

  • Added a container for better alignment.

  • Used a modern and clean design with orange accents.

  • Includes hover effects and improved typography.

Styled Next.js Component:

js
"use client";

import React, { useState } from "react";
import axios from "axios";

const Result = () => {
  const [studentId, setStudentId] = useState("");
  const [status, setStatus] = useState("");
  const [loading, setLoading] = useState(false);

  const checkStatus = async () => {
    if (!studentId) {
      setStatus("Please enter a valid student ID.");
      return;
    }
    setLoading(true);
    setStatus("");

    try {
      const response = await axios.get(`/api/status?id=${studentId}`);
      const result = response.data.status;
      if (result === "Approved" || result === "Rejected") {
        setStatus(result);
      } else {
        setStatus("ID not found");
      }
    } catch (error) {
      setStatus("Error retrieving status. Please try again later.");
    } finally {
      setLoading(false);
    }
  };

  return (
    <>
      <section className="bg-dark-navy">
        <div className="container d-flex flex-column justify-content-center align-items-center py-5">
          <h2 className="display-1 text-light text-center">Recruitment Result</h2>
          <p className="text-light text-center lead">
            Applied to become a member?
          </p>
        </div>
      </section>
      <div className="container my-5">
        <div className="row justify-content-center">
          <div className="col-lg-6 col-md-8 col-sm-10">
            <div className="card p-4 shadow border-0">
              <h3 className="fw-bold text-center text-orange">
                Application Status
              </h3>
              <p className="text-center">
                Enter your student ID to check application status:
              </p>
              <input
                type="text"
                className="form-control mb-3"
                placeholder="Enter Student ID"
                value={studentId}
                onChange={(e) => setStudentId(e.target.value)}
                style={{ borderColor: "#ff6600" }}
              />
              <button
                className="btn btn-orange w-100"
                onClick={checkStatus}
                disabled={loading}
              >
                {loading ? "Checking..." : "Check Status"}
              </button>
              {status && (
                <div
                  className={`mt-3 alert ${
                    status === "Approved"
                      ? "alert-success"
                      : status === "Rejected"
                      ? "alert-danger"
                      : "alert-warning"
                  }`}
                >
                  {status}
                </div>
              )}
            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </div>
    </>
  );
};

export default Result;

Custom CSS:

Add this in your global CSS file or in a module:

css
.text-orange {
  color: #ff6600;
}

.btn-orange {
  background-color: #ff6600;
  color: white;
  border: none;
  transition: background-color 0.3s ease;
}

.btn-orange:hover {
  background-color: #e65c00;
}

.card {
  border-radius: 15px;
}

input:focus {
  box-shadow: 0 0 5px rgba(255, 102, 0, 0.5);
  outline: none;
  border-color: #ff6600;
}

UI Improvements:

  • Container: Centered and responsive with balanced padding.

  • Accent Color: Used orange (#ff6600) for buttons and headings.

  • Button Hover: Smooth transition for hover effects.

  • Alerts: Different colors for Approved, Rejected, and ID not found.

  • Input Field: Styled focus effect with orange shadow.

This should give your form a clean and modern look while maintaining a consistent theme. If you need further adjustments or animations, let me know!

You said:
success alert dark green bg
ChatGPT said:

Here are the changes to make the success alert have a dark green background:

Updated Component:

js
"use client";

import React, { useState } from "react";
import axios from "axios";

const Result = () => {
  const [studentId, setStudentId] = useState("");
  const [status, setStatus] = useState("");
  const [loading, setLoading] = useState(false);

  const checkStatus = async () => {
    if (!studentId) {
      setStatus("Please enter a valid student ID.");
      return;
    }
    setLoading(true);
    setStatus("");

    try {
      const response = await axios.get(`/api/status?id=${studentId}`);
      const result = response.data.status;
      if (result === "Approved" || result === "Rejected") {
        setStatus(result);
      } else {
        setStatus("ID not found");
      }
    } catch (error) {
      setStatus("Error retrieving status. Please try again later.");
    } finally {
      setLoading(false);
    }
  };

  return (
    <>
      <section className="bg-dark-navy">
        <div className="container d-flex flex-column justify-content-center align-items-center py-5">
          <h2 className="display-1 text-light text-center">Recruitment Result</h2>
          <p className="text-light text-center lead">
            Applied to become a member?
          </p>
        </div>
      </section>
      <div className="container my-5">
        <div className="row justify-content-center">
          <div className="col-lg-6 col-md-8 col-sm-10">
            <div className="card p-4 shadow border-0">
              <h3 className="fw-bold text-orange text-center">
                Application Status
              </h3>
              <p className="text-center">
                Enter your student ID to check application status:
              </p>
              <input
                type="text"
                className="form-control mb-3"
                placeholder="Enter Student ID"
                value={studentId}
                onChange={(e) => setStudentId(e.target.value)}
                style={{ borderColor: "#ff6600" }}
              />
              <button
                className="btn btn-orange w-100"
                onClick={checkStatus}
                disabled={loading}
              >
                {loading ? "Checking..." : "Check Status"}
              </button>
              {status && (
                <div
                  className={`mt-3 alert ${
                    status === "Approved"
                      ? "alert-success-dark"
                      : status === "Rejected"
                      ? "alert-danger"
                      : "alert-warning"
                  }`}
                >
                  {status}
                </div>
              )}
            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </div>
    </>
  );
};

export default Result;

Updated Custom CSS:

Add this to your global CSS file or module:

css
.text-orange {
  color: #ff6600;
}

.btn-orange {
  background-color: #ff6600;
  color: white;
  border: none;
  transition: background-color 0.3s ease;
}

.btn-orange:hover {
  background-color: #e65c00;
}

.card {
  border-radius: 15px;
}

input:focus {
  box-shadow: 0 0 5px rgba(255, 102, 0, 0.5);
  outline: none;
  border-color: #ff6600;
}

/* Dark Green Success Alert */
.alert-success-dark {
  background-color: #2f4f2f;
  color: #ffffff;
  border: none;
  border-radius: 5px;
}

What's Changed:

  • Dark Green Success Alert: Now uses #2f4f2f for the background with white text.

  • Consistent Styling: Maintained the orange accents and hover effects.

This should give your alerts a more professional and clean look. If you need further adjustments, feel free to ask!

You said:
problem ./app/layout.tsx Error: x Unexpected token html. Expected jsx identifier ,-[/home/zaidfahad/Documents/Jukti_Iub_Web/JUKTI/app/layout.tsx:20:1] 20 | children: React.ReactNode 21 | }) { 22 | return ( 23 | <html lang="en"> : ^^^^ 24 | <body className={quicksand.className}> 25 | <div className="sticky-top "><NavBar /></div> 26 | <div>{children}</div> ---- Caused by: Syntax Error code import './globals.css' import './sass/main.css' import './sass/main.min.css' import NavBar from './components/navbar' import Footer from "./components/footer" import {Quicksand } from 'next/font/google' const quicksand = Quicksand({ // weight: ['400', '700'], subsets: ['latin'], }) export const metadata = { title: 'JUKTI', description: 'jukti', } export default function RootLayout({ children, }: { children: React.ReactNode }) { return ( <html lang="en"> <body className={quicksand.className}> <div className="sticky-top "><NavBar /></div> <div>{children}</div> <div><Footer/><div> </body> </html> ) }
ChatGPT said:

The issue is due to a syntax error in the layout.tsx file. Specifically, you have an unclosed <div> tag near the end of the component.

Fix:

Change this:

tsx
<div><Footer/><div>

To this:

tsx
<div><Footer/></div>

Updated Code:

tsx
import './globals.css'
import './sass/main.css'
import './sass/main.min.css'
import NavBar from './components/navbar'
import Footer from "./components/footer"
import { Quicksand } from 'next/font/google'

const quicksand = Quicksand({
  subsets: ['latin'],
})

export const metadata = {
  title: 'JUKTI',
  description: 'jukti',
}

export default function RootLayout({
  children,
}: {
  children: React.ReactNode
}) {
  return (
    <html lang="en">
      <body className={quicksand.className}>
        <div className="sticky-top">
          <NavBar />
        </div>
        <div>{children}</div> 
        <div>
          <Footer />
        </div>
      </body>
    </html>
  )
}

What's Changed:

  • Fixed Closing Tag: Properly closed the <div> containing <Footer />.

This should resolve the Unexpected token html error. If you face any other issues, feel free to ask!

You said:
make this page take full height import React from 'react' import Result from "../components/result"; const page = () => { return ( <> <Result/> </> ) } export default page
ChatGPT said:

To make this page take the full height, you should add a CSS class that applies min-height: 100vh (100% of the viewport height) to the root container. Here's how to do it:

Update Code:

tsx
import React from 'react'
import Result from "../components/result";

const Page = () => {
  return (
    <div className="min-vh-100 d-flex flex-column">
      <Result/>
    </div>
  )
}

export default Page;

What's Changed:

  • Added Wrapper <div>: This wrapper ensures the page takes up the full height.

  • Applied Bootstrap Classes:

    • min-vh-100: Sets the minimum height to 100% of the viewport.

    • d-flex flex-column: Ensures the content is arranged in a column, taking full height.

This approach leverages Bootstrap utility classes, assuming Bootstrap is already integrated into your project. If not, you can add this in your global CSS:

Global CSS (if not using Bootstrap):

css
.full-height {
  min-height: 100vh;
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: column;
}

Then change the className to:

tsx
<div className="full-height">

This will make the page take the full height. If you need more adjustments, let me know!

"Checking..." : "Check Status"} </button> {status && ( <div className={mt-3 alert ${ status === "Approved" ? "alert-success-dark" : status === "Rejected" ? "alert-danger" : "alert-warning" }} > {status} </div> )} </div> </div> </div> </div> </> ); }; export default Result;
ChatGPT said:

To space the form elements evenly and enhance the overall design, you can use Bootstrap's utility classes and a few custom styles. Here's the updated version:

Updated Code:

jsx
"use client";

import React, { useState } from "react";
import axios from "axios";
import "./result.css";

const Result = () => {
  const [studentId, setStudentId] = useState("");
  const [status, setStatus] = useState("");
  const [loading, setLoading] = useState(false);

  const checkStatus = async () => {
    if (!studentId) {
      setStatus("Please enter a valid student ID.");
      return;
    }
    setLoading(true);
    setStatus("");

    try {
      // const response = await axios.get(`/api/status?id=${studentId}`);
      // const result = response.data.status;
      const result = "Approved";
      if (result === "Approved" || result === "Rejected") {
        setStatus(result);
      } else {
        setStatus("ID not found");
      }
    } catch (error) {
      setStatus("Error retrieving status. Please try again later.");
    } finally {
      setLoading(false);
    }
  };

  return (
    <>
      <section className="bg-dark-navy">
        <div className="container d-flex flex-column justify-content-center align-items-center py-5">
          <h2 className="display-1 text-light text-center">Recruitment Result</h2>
          <p className="text-light text-center lead">
            Applied to become a member?
          </p>
        </div>
      </section>
      <div className="container my-5">
        <div className="row justify-content-center">
          <div className="col-lg-6 col-md-8 col-sm-10">
            <div className="card p-4 shadow border-0 d-flex flex-column gap-3">
              <h3 className="fw-bold text-center text-orange">
                Application Status
              </h3>
              <p className="text-center">
                Enter your student ID to check application status:
              </p>
              <input
                type="text"
                className="form-control"
                placeholder="Enter Student ID"
                value={studentId}
                onChange={(e) => setStudentId(e.target.value)}
                style={{ borderColor: "#ff6600" }}
              />
              <button
                className="btn btn-orange w-100"
                onClick={checkStatus}
                disabled={loading}
              >
                {loading ? "Checking..." : "Check Status"}
              </button>
              {status && (
                <div
                  className={`alert mt-3 ${
                    status === "Approved"
                      ? "alert-success-dark"
                      : status === "Rejected"
                      ? "alert-danger"
                      : "alert-warning"
                  }`}
                >
                  {status}
                </div>
              )}
            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </div>
    </>
  );
};

export default Result;

What's Changed:

  1. Added d-flex flex-column gap-3 to the Card: This evenly spaces the elements.

  2. Consistent Padding and Margins: Using Bootstrap's utility classes for better spacing.

  3. Minimal Custom Styles: Only the border color for the input is custom, to maintain the accent color.

Additional CSS (Optional):

If you want to refine the alert style and buttons, add this to your result.css:

css
.text-orange {
  color: #ff6600;
}

.btn-orange {
  background-color: #ff6600;
  color: #fff;
  border: none;
}

.btn-orange:hover {
  background-color: #e65c00;
}

.alert-success-dark {
  background-color: #155724;
  color: #fff;
}

This should make the form look more visually appealing and neatly spaced! If you need more adjustments, let me know.

Please try again later."); } finally { setLoading(false); } }; return ( <> <section className="bg-dark-navy "> <div className="container d-flex flex-column justify-content-center align-items-center py-5"> <h2 className="display-1 text-light text-center">Recruitment Result</h2> <p className="text-light text-center lead"> Applied to become a member? </p> </div> </section> <div className="container m-50"> <div className="row justify-content-center"> <div className="col-lg-6 col-md-8 col-sm-10"> <div className="card p-4 shadow border-0"> <h3 className="fw-bold text-center text-orange"> Application Status </h3> <p className="text-center"> Enter your student ID to check application status: </p> <input type="text" className="form-control mb-3" placeholder="Enter Student ID" value={studentId} onChange={(e) => setStudentId(e.target.value)} style={{ borderColor: "#ff6600" }} /> <button className="btn btn-orange w-100" onClick={checkStatus} disabled={loading} > {loading ? "Checking..." : "Check Status"} </button> {status && ( <div className={mt-3 alert ${ status === "Approved" ? "alert-success-dark" : status === "Rejected" ? "alert-danger" : "alert-warning" }} > {status} </div> )} </div> </div> </div> </div> </> ); }; export default Result;
ChatGPT said:

To add margin around the form container, you can use Bootstrap's margin utility class m-5 or a custom class to define more specific spacing. I'll update the code with the margin adjustment.

Updated Code:

jsx
"use client";

import React, { useState } from "react";
import axios from "axios";
import "./result.css";

const Result = () => {
  const [studentId, setStudentId] = useState("");
  const [status, setStatus] = useState("");
  const [loading, setLoading] = useState(false);

  const checkStatus = async () => {
    if (!studentId) {
      setStatus("Please enter a valid student ID.");
      return;
    }
    setLoading(true);
    setStatus("");

    try {
      // const response = await axios.get(`/api/status?id=${studentId}`);
      // const result = response.data.status;
      const result = "Approved";
      if (result === "Approved" || result === "Rejected") {
        setStatus(result);
      } else {
        setStatus("ID not found");
      }
    } catch (error) {
      setStatus("Error retrieving status. Please try again later.");
    } finally {
      setLoading(false);
    }
  };

  return (
    <>
      <section className="bg-dark-navy">
        <div className="container d-flex flex-column justify-content-center align-items-center py-5">
          <h2 className="display-1 text-light text-center">Recruitment Result</h2>
          <p className="text-light text-center lead">
            Applied to become a member?
          </p>
        </div>
      </section>
      <div className="container m-5">
        <div className="row justify-content-center">
          <div className="col-lg-6 col-md-8 col-sm-10">
            <div className="card p-4 shadow border-0">
              <h3 className="fw-bold text-center text-orange">
                Application Status
              </h3>
              <p className="text-center">
                Enter your student ID to check application status:
              </p>
              <input
                type="text"
                className="form-control mb-3"
                placeholder="Enter Student ID"
                value={studentId}
                onChange={(e) => setStudentId(e.target.value)}
                style={{ borderColor: "#ff6600" }}
              />
              <button
                className="btn btn-orange w-100"
                onClick={checkStatus}
                disabled={loading}
              >
                {loading ? "Checking..." : "Check Status"}
              </button>
              {status && (
                <div
                  className={`mt-3 alert ${
                    status === "Approved"
                      ? "alert-success-dark"
                      : status === "Rejected"
                      ? "alert-danger"
                      : "alert-warning"
                  }`}
                >
                  {status}
                </div>
              )}
            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </div>
    </>
  );
};

export default Result;

Key Changes:

  • Container Margin: Changed the class from m-50 to m-5 on the form container to ensure proper margin around the form. You can adjust this value (m-5, m-4, etc.) as needed for the desired spacing.

Additional Notes:

  • m-5 adds margin around the container. You can adjust this number based on your design needs.

  • Optional Custom Margin: If you want more specific control over margin sizes, you can add a custom class and define the margin in the CSS:

css
.custom-margin {
  margin: 50px;
}

Then add the class to the container like so:

jsx
<div className="container custom-margin">

This will ensure that the form container is spaced appropriately.
